summary_points: 1. Effective May 9, 2025, W.W. Grainger, Inc. eliminated cumulative voting and significantly altered its shareholder nomination process for the board of directors.
2. As of May 15, 2025, twelve exhibits related to amended bylaws have been added to the SEC filing, suggesting significant ongoing legal or regulatory issues.
3.  The company filed an 8-K on May 15, 2025, indicating a material event requiring disclosure.

1. Essex Property Trust, Inc. held its annual meeting on May 13, 2025, where stockholders elected nine directors and ratified KPMG LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for the year ending December 31, 2025.

2.  While most director elections saw a large majority of "for" votes,  Irving F. Lyons, III received significantly less support (52,463,811 "for" votes out of 64,325,580 outstanding shares), and George M. Marcus received even less (53,876,249 "for" votes).
3. The advisory vote to approve named executive officer compensation resulted in 51,255,480 votes "for," 3,842,904 votes "against," and 2,108,890 broker non-votes, as of May 13, 2025.

1. On May 13, 2025, Cummins Inc. held its 2025 annual meeting, where shareholders voted on the election of eleven directors, an advisory vote on executive compensation, the ratification of PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as auditors, and a shareholder proposal regarding an independent board chairman.

2.  At the Annual Meeting, approximately 85.7% of outstanding shares voted, with the shareholder proposal for an independent board chairman receiving significantly fewer "For" votes (43,023,230) compared to "Against" votes (60,921,624).

3. The election of the eleven directors was approved by a substantial majority of shareholders; however,  the significant opposition to the independent board chairman proposal may indicate future challenges in board governance.
1. Veralto Corp eliminated its classified board structure and supermajority voting requirements, effective May 15, 2025, following a shareholder vote with 94.7% approval.
2. Annual director elections will begin in 2026.
3.  The shareholder vote on May 14, 2025, involved approximately 226,234,934 total votes.

1. Leidos Holdings, Inc. will temporarily suspend trading under its employee benefit plans from the week of June 29, 2025, to the week of July 20, 2025, due to administrative changes including a recordkeeper and trustee change.
2.  Directors and executive officers are prohibited from trading Leidos Holdings, Inc. common stock (including derivatives) from the afternoon of July 2, 2025, to the afternoon of July 25, 2025.
3.  Plan participants will be unable to make changes to their plan accounts during the blackout period, including changing contribution rates, directing investments, or making withdrawals.

1. Louisville Gas and Electric Company (LG&E) and Kentucky Utilities Company (KU) plan to request a combined $381 million increase in annual electricity and gas revenues from the Kentucky Public Service Commission (KPSC), starting May 30, 2025.

2.  If approved by the KPSC (anticipated ruling in Q4 2025), the rate increases would be 8.3% and 11.5% for LG&E and KU electricity, respectively, and 14% for LG&E natural gas, taking effect January 1, 2026.
3.  The companies cite aging infrastructure (e.g., 55% of wooden transmission poles are over 60 years old) and increased extreme weather events as justification for the revenue increases.
1. As of April 30, 2025, American Express's U.S. Consumer Card Member loans totaled $90.7 billion, with a net write-off rate of 2.0% (principal only).
2.  Compared to February 28, 2025, the total U.S. Consumer and Small Business Card Member loans increased by $4.3 billion to $122.3 billion as of April 30, 2025.

3. The reported credit performance of the American Express Credit Account Master Trust may differ from the total U.S. Consumer or U.S. Small Business Card Member loan portfolios due to variations in loan characteristics and calculation methods.
1. On May 12, 2025, Caterpillar Inc. issued $1.7 billion in 5.200% Senior Notes due 2035 and $300 million in 5.500% Senior Notes due 2055.
2. The sale of the notes, which closed on May 15, 2025, will be used for general corporate purposes, potentially including debt repayment.
3.  The notes bear interest at 5.200% and 5.500% per year, respectively, payable semi-annually, commencing November 15, 2025.

1. Phillips 66 is selling a 65% stake in its German and Austrian retail marketing business to a consortium for approximately €1.5 billion ($1.6 billion) in pre-tax cash proceeds, with the transaction expected to close in the second half of 2025.

2.  The transaction values the Germany and Austria retail marketing business at an enterprise value of approximately €2.5 billion ($2.8 billion), representing an implied Enterprise Value/EBITDA multiple of 9.1x based on expected 2025 EBITDA.
3. Phillips 66 will retain a 35% non-operated interest in the newly formed joint venture and has signed a multi-year agreement to supply the business with fuel from the MiRO Refinery.
1. On May 14, 2025, Intuitive Surgical, Inc. appointed David J. Rosa as Chief Executive Officer, effective July 1, 2025, replacing Gary S. Guthart, who will become Executive Chair.

2.  Effective July 1, 2025, Dr. Guthart's base salary will decrease from $1,050,000 to $700,000, while Mr. Rosa's will increase from $825,000 to $925,000, and his targeted bonus opportunity will increase from 125% to 150% of his base salary.  Mr. Rosa will also receive stock grants valued at $8,000,000.
3. Mr. Rosa's promotion is a result of the Board's succession planning and reflects his significant contributions to Intuitive's strategy, product development, and global expansion.

1. Equity Residential and its operating partnership, ERP Operating Limited Partnership, entered into a distribution agreement on May 15, 2025, to sell up to 13,000,000 common shares through an "at the market" offering program.

2.  The agreement allows for the sale of up to 13,000,000 shares,  previously authorized but unsold under an expired prospectus supplement, with agents receiving commissions not exceeding 2.0% of the gross sales price.

3. The automatic shelf registration statement filed on May 13, 2025, replaces one expiring on May 17, 2025, and the company also maintains a separate share repurchase program with authorization for the repurchase of up to 13,000,000 common shares.
1. Tractor Supply Company declared a $0.23 per share cash dividend on May 15, 2025, payable June 10, 2025, to stockholders of record as of May 28, 2025.
2. As of March 29, 2025, the company operated 2,311 Tractor Supply stores and 206 Petsense by Tractor Supply stores.
3.  No specific future impacts or risks are mentioned in the provided text.
1. On May 14, 2025, Akamai Technologies Inc. priced a $1.5 billion private offering of convertible senior notes due 2033, upsized from a previously announced $1.35 billion offering.

2. Akamai estimates net proceeds of approximately $1.479 billion (or $1.701 billion if the option to purchase additional notes is exercised in full) will be used to repay debt and repurchase approximately $300 million of its common stock at $77.51 per share.

3.  The convertible senior notes include an optional repurchase date on May 15, 2031, and a fundamental change repurchase clause, both allowing note holders to require Akamai to repurchase the notes under specific circumstances.
1. Walmart's Q1 fiscal year 2026 revenue grew 2.5% year-over-year (4.0% in constant currency), while operating income increased by 4.3% (3.0% adjusted constant currency).
2. Walmart's Q2 fiscal year 2026 net sales are projected to increase by 3.5% to 4.5% (constant currency), but  no specific guidance was given for operating income growth or EPS due to uncertainty.

3.  Walmart has identified a potential material weakness in its internal controls over financial reporting, potentially leading to financial statement restatements for prior periods and increased regulatory scrutiny.
1. Deere & Company experienced a 24% year-over-year decrease in Q2 2025 net income, reaching $1.804 billion.
2.  Worldwide net sales and revenues for the first half of fiscal year 2025 decreased by 22% compared to the same period in 2024, totaling $21.272 billion.
3. Deere & Company forecasts a net income range of $4.75 billion to $5.50 billion for fiscal year 2025, a broadened outlook reflecting uncertainty in the operating environment as of May 15, 2025.
1. Ventas, Inc. increased its authorized shares of common stock from 600,000,000 to 1,200,000,000 on May 14, 2025.

2.  At the May 13, 2025 Annual Meeting, shareholder approval for limiting the liability of certain officers (Proposal 5) received 322,346,567 votes for, and 60,932,600 votes against, with 319,312 abstentions and 18,054,520 broker non-votes.

3.  The amendments to Ventas, Inc.'s Certificate of Incorporation, filed May 14, 2025, include changes to increase authorized shares and limit officer liability, potentially impacting future fundraising and risk management.

1. At the May 14, 2025, Annual Meeting of Shareholders, a shareholder proposal requesting a report on the effectiveness of Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion efforts was not approved, receiving only 26,240,205 votes in favor versus 160,685,853 against.
2.  Three directors, Susan D. DeVore, Bahija Jallal, and Ryan M. Schneider, were elected to serve three-year terms expiring in 2028.
3. The advisory vote on executive compensation was approved at the May 14, 2025, shareholder meeting, with 173,964,580 votes in favor.
1. John Wren's employment agreement with Omnicom Group Inc. has been amended, extending his term as Chairman and CEO until December 31, 2028, after which he will become Executive Chairman.
2.  Wren's annual base salary will be reduced to $1.00 effective June 1, 2025, but he will receive a stock option to purchase 4,000,000 shares of Omnicom common stock.
3. Omnicom faces risks related to its pending merger with IPG, including potential delays, unanticipated costs, regulatory hurdles, employee loss, and failure to realize expected benefits.

1. At the 2025 Annual Meeting on May 13, 2025, shareholders elected eleven nominees to the Board of Directors for a one-year term and ratified PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP as the independent registered public accounting firm for 2025.

2.  Shareholder votes on Proposal 3 (advisory approval of Named Executive Officer compensation) showed 336,261,144 votes FOR, 33,196,823 votes AGAINST, and 2,193,603 abstentions, with 75,702,306 broker non-votes.
3.  There were no noteworthy regulatory or legal developments mentioned in this filing.
1. At Waste Management Inc.'s May 13, 2025 annual meeting, 344,396,906 shares (85.5% of outstanding shares) voted, electing all nine director nominees.
2.  Shareholder approval of Ernst & Young LLP as the independent auditor for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2025, was relatively strong, with 321,370,355 shares voting in favor (79.8%).
3.  Advisory approval of executive compensation received comparatively lower support, with 281,636,584 shares voting for the proposal (69.9%).
